sect2.title: Setting up ethernet cards
sect2.para: Ethernet cards can be configured by selecting expert and then eth in the network configuration. The resulting screen () provides several options:

listitem.para: modules: This option is used to load modules (drivers) for the network adapters that you want to use.
edit: You can configure the settings for an network interface, like the IP address, and default route with this option.
remove: The remove option is used to remove the configuration for an interface.

sect2.para: Interfaces are named in Linux, example names are eth2, lo and ppp0. Normal (ethernet) network interfaces are named ethn, in which n is a number starting with 0. For example, the first network card is named eth0, the second eth1, etc.

sect3.title: Editing an interface
sect3.para: You can configure an interface by selecting the edit menu option described above. The next dialog will ask you which interface you would like to configure (. Select the interface you would like to configure to proceed.

sect2.title: Configuring DNS
sect2.para: DNS servers have a very special task in networking. They translate hostnames (for instance www.libranet.com) to IP addresses. To be able to use hostnames the system needs access to one or more DNS servers. Almost all Internet service providers provide DNS servers. DNS can be configured by selecting expert and then nameserver in the adminmenu network configuration. Adminmenu will then ask for the nameservers (). You can enter the IP addresses in the input field, separating them with a space.

sect1.title: Manual configuration
sect1.para: This chapter explains how some common network-related configuration files work. Most things can be configured with adminmenu, but more experienced users might prefer configuring things by editing the relevant configuration files.

sect2.title: Local hosts
sect2.para: Besides resolving using name servers specified in /etc/resolv.conf, GNU/Linux can also resolve hosts that are specified in /etc/hosts. This file is handy for adding names to local hosts, without the hassle of configuring a local name server. Hosts are specified in the following form: <IP address> <name1> ... <namen>. note.para: If you want to use the same hosts file on a relatively large number of machines, it might we worth looking at the dnsmasq package. Dnsmasq can provide a hosts file on one host to a complete network through its DNS server.
